g.text: A Review of Recent Advances in Research on Extreme Heat Events.
(eds), Explaining Extreme Events of 2014 from A Climate Perspective, Special Supplement to
7. IPCC. Managing the Risks of Extreme Events and Disasters to Advance Climate Change Adaptation. A Special Report of Working
Groups I and II of the Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change (Field, C. B., V. Barros, T. F. Stocker, D. Qin, D. J. Dokken, K. L.
Ebi, M. D. Mastrandrea, K. J. Mach, G.-K. Plattner, S. K. Allen, M. Tignor, and P. M. Midgley (eds)). Cambridge University Press,
Cambridge, UK, and New York, NY, USA, 582 pp. (2012).
9. Meehl G. A. & Tebaldi, C. More intense, more frequent, and longer lasting heat waves in the 21st century.
10. Rahmstorf, S. & Coumou, D. Increase of extreme events in a warming world. P
11. Coumou, D., Robinson, A. & Rahmstorf, S. Global increase in record-breaking monthly-mean temperatures.
12. Christidis, N., Jones, G. S. & Stott, P. A. Dramatically increasing chance of extremely hot summers since the 2003 European
13. Trenberth, K. E., Fasullo, J. T. & Shepherd, T. G. Attribution of climate extreme events,
14. Westra, S., Alexander, L. V. & Zwiers, F. W. Global Increasing Trends in Annual Maximum Daily Precipitation.
15. Lehmann, J., Coumou, D. & Frieler, K. Increased record-breaking precipitation events under global warming.
16. Coumou, D. & Rahmstorf, S. A decade of weather extremes.
The role of increasing temperature variability in European summer heatwaves.
Soil moisture-atmosphere interactions during the 2003 European summer heat wave.
19. Coumou, D., Lehmann, J. & Beckmann, J. The weakening summer circulation in the Northern Hemisphere mid-latitudes.
20. Diffenbaugh, N. S., Swain, D. L. & Touma, D. Anthropogenic warming has increased drought risk in California.
21. Trenberth, K. E. & Fasullo, J. T. Climate extremes and climate change: The Russian heat wave and other climate extremes of 2010.
22. Sewall, J. O. & Sloan, L. C. Disappearing Arctic sea ice reduces available water in the American west,
23. Francis, J. A. & Vavrus, S. J. Evidence linking Arctic amplification to extreme weather in mid-latitudes.
24. Chang, E. K. M., Ma, C., Zheng, C. & Yau, A. M. W. Observed and projected decrease in Northern Hemisphere extratropical cyclone
activity in summer and its impacts on maximum temperature.
25. Petrie, R. E., Shaffrey, L. C. & Sutton, R. T. Atmospheric response in summer linked to recent Arctic sea ice loss.
Future changes in extratropical storm tracks and baroclinicity under climate change,
27. Hoskins, B. J. &Karoly, D. The Steady Linear Response of a Spherical Atmosphere to Thermal and Orographic Forcing.
28. Hoskins, B. J. & Ambrizzi, T. Rossby Wave Propagation on a Realistic Longitudinally Varying Flow,
29. Petoukhov, V., Rahmstorf, S., Petri, S. & Schellnhuber, H. J. Reply to Screen and Simmonds: From means to mechanisms,
30. Hoskins, B. & Woollings, T. Persistent Extratropical Regimes and Climate Extremes,
32. Hewitson, B. C. & Crane, R. G. Consensus between GCM climate change projections with empirical downscaling: precipitation
33. Ning, L., Mann, M. E., Crane, R. & Wagener, T. Probabilistic Projections of Climate Change for the Mid-Atlantic Region of the
United States - Validation of Precipitation Downscaling During the Historical Era.
34. Woollings, T., Hannachi, A. & Hoskins, B. Variability of the North Atlantic eddy-driven jet stream.
35. Davini, P. & Cagnazzo, C. On the misinterpretation of the North Atlantic Oscillation in CMIP5 models,
Assessing mid-latitude dynamics in extreme event attribution systems,
37. Shepherd, T. G. Atmospheric circulation as a source of uncertainty in climate change projections.
Climate Change 2013: The Physical Science Basis - Summary for Policymakers. In Climate change 2013: the physical
science basis. Working Group I contribution to the Fifth Assessment Report of the Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change, eds
39. Hansen, J., Ruedy, R., Sato, M. & Lo, K. Global surface temperature change.
40. Morice, C., Kennedy, J., Rayner, N. & Jones, P. Quantifying uncertainties in global and regional temperature change using an
ensemble of observational estimates: The HadCRUT4 data set.
41. Cowtan, K. & Way, R. Coverage bias in the HadCRUT4 temperature series and its impact on recent temperature trends.
All raw data, ©Matlab code, and results from our analysis are available at the supplementary website: http://
www.meteo.psu.edu/~mann/supplements/. We acknowledge the World Climate Research Programme’s Working
Group on Coupled Modelling, which is responsible for CMIP, and we thank the climate modeling groups for
producing and making available their model output. D.C. and K.K. were supported by the BMBF.
